sections.content: [Full name not specified] is registered with the Medical Council of Ireland (MCI 513952 — Active) and the Pakistan Medical Council (757002-01-M). He can be contacted at muhammadzohaibbinnawaz@gmail.com and on +92 331 6943534. [City, Country not specified]. [Right-to-work/visa status for Ireland not specified]. A LinkedIn profile can be added if available.

Medical Officer (Registrar level) with experience across nephrology, critical care and emergency medicine in busy tertiary and primary care settings. Comfortable working within consultant-led teams, escalating early and adhering to guidelines such as KDIGO and NICE. Recent work includes managing renal emergencies, supporting ICU and ED on-calls, and contributing to dialysis unit service improvement through SOP development and rota design. He teaches regularly in the department and at undergraduate level, and participates in audits and QIPs, including dialysis quality and CT head indication compliance. He was recently recognised as Employee of the Quarter at his current hospital. He aims to contribute to the Irish healthcare system while progressing towards MRCPI training.

Medical Officer (Registrar level) — Recep Tayyip Erdogan Hospital, Muzaffargarh (semi-government tertiary care, ~500 beds; catchment ~4 million) — Mar 2024 – Present. In this consultant-led nephrology service, he provides registrar-level cover for the nephrology unit and participates in on-call coverage for medical wards, ICU and the Emergency Department. His work includes assessing and managing renal emergencies, coordinating care for patients with AKI and CKD, and supporting maintenance haemodialysis pathways. Under consultant supervision he has gained experience with ultrasound-guided renal biopsy and venous access for dialysis. He contributes to departmental teaching, rota management and quality improvement, including an anaemia eradication programme that he proposed and now leads under consultant oversight. He developed SOPs for the dialysis unit that continue to be used locally. He was selected as Employee of the Quarter for his contributions to service delivery and team support. A recent example involved a patient with suspected sepsis and AKI in ED: he initiated the sepsis pathway, arranged urgent labs and ultrasound, escalated to the registrar and consultant, and coordinated with dialysis nursing for timely dialysis planning, documenting handover with ISBAR. This reinforced early escalation, bundle-driven care and clear safety-netting in similar cases.

Medical Officer — Javed Clinic, Murree — Jun 2023 – Feb 2024. In this primary care setting he assessed and treated common infections and chronic disease exacerbations such as COPD and asthma, and stabilised emergencies including trauma prior to referral. He provided follow-up for diabetes, hypertension and cardiovascular disease, counselling patients on adherence and red flags. He used local referral pathways and discussed complex cases with senior colleagues as needed. One example included stabilising a suspected DKA case with fluids and insulin per protocol, arranging transfer and communicating with the receiving team using a structured handover, which supported a safe transition and timely definitive care.

House Officer — Nishtar Hospital, Multan (tertiary centre ~2,000 beds; high-volume ED) — Jun 2022 – Jun 2023. Rotations included Neurosurgery, General Surgery, Psychiatry and General Medicine. He participated in the conservative and perioperative management of intracranial bleeds and spine trauma under close consultant and registrar supervision, supported the acute surgical take, and contributed to the care of patients with malignant hypertension, diabetic ketoacidosis, COPD exacerbations, gastritis, AKI, ACS and stroke. He reviewed imaging at the workstation with seniors and documented agreed plans. In Psychiatry, he worked in OPD alongside the consultant, seeing patients with ADHD, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and depression, and learned to prioritise risk assessment, capacity and safety planning.

MBBS — 2022, Nishtar Medical University, Multan.
OET — 2023: Listening A, Reading A, Speaking B, Writing B. IELTS status: [Scores and date not specified].
Relevant learning applied to practice includes using sepsis bundles and early escalation during acute deterioration, and structured documentation during handovers.

His procedural exposure includes ultrasound-guided renal biopsy, femoral venous catheter insertion for dialysis, diagnostic and therapeutic ascitic and pleural taps, lumbar puncture (sitting and lateral), and maintenance of IV access and blood sampling. He performs these within a supervised framework, adhering to sterile technique, ultrasound guidance where appropriate, post-procedure monitoring and clear escalation plans. For example, following a renal biopsy he ensured blood pressure control, monitored haemoglobin and observed for flank pain, escalating promptly to the consultant if concerns arose. Estimated volumes and supervision levels are available on request: [Volumes/supervision not specified].

He teaches regularly in the nephrology department and in other units such as ICU and paediatrics, tailoring content to a mixed audience of doctors and nurses. During his house job he delivered bedside teaching to 3rd-year medical students on history taking and common topics in one-to-one sessions. He delivered a psychiatric awareness lecture to approximately 200 attendees at Islamia University Bahawalpur, using case vignettes to build engagement. He incorporates feedback and aims to measure impact through simple tools such as pre/post questions and brief evaluations. Feedback metrics and teaching frequency are available on request: [Details not specified].

He completed a dialysis unit QIP against KDIGO standards, and wrote SOPs that remain in use locally. He ran three PDSA cycles to improve compliance with NICE head injury CT indications in ED, introducing practical prompts and checklists and re-measuring after implementing changes. He serves on the hospital Electronic Medical Record Review Committee, contributing a clinical perspective to system optimisation. Research: Frequency of Cardiomyopathies in patients with End-Stage Renal Disease on Maintenance Haemodialysis; IRB approval obtained; projected completion by mid‑Nov 2025. Baselines, re-measurement data and dissemination details will be added: [Metrics and outputs not specified].

He coordinates dialysis unit scheduling and waiting lists under consultant supervision, balancing clinical demand with staff availability. He holds fortnightly staff meetings in the nephrology department and manages rota planning, including redesign during Eid to ensure all patients received timely dialysis while staff secured leave. He focuses on early identification of bottlenecks, clear communication and maintaining safe staffing, and he hands over processes to sustain improvements.

He works within consultant-led teams across nephrology, ICU and ED, escalating early for deteriorating patients and using ISBAR for handover. He prioritises patient and family communication, using teach-back to confirm understanding and written advice for safety-netting. For example, he explained AKI management and fluid balance to a family, checked understanding through teach-back and arranged appropriate follow-up, which improved adherence and early recognition of red flags.

meta.notes: Time Investment & Application Strategy: Invest 20–30 hours to restructure your CV into evidence-led, ATS-ready sections with STAR/CAMP examples; then spend 1–2 hours tailoring per post. Plan: 1) Normalise formatting (MMM YYYY, en dashes) and separate Degrees vs CPD; 2) Rewrite Employment History with 2–3 STAR achievements per role, adding supervision/escalation; 3) Complete QIP cycles with baseline→intervention→re-measure→dissemination and add results; 4) Add a focused Personal Statement aligned to Irish registrar posts (safety, communication, QIP); 5) Gather feedback metrics for teaching and procedure volumes/supervision to evidence competence.
